courseTitle: The Effect of Light on Seed Germination

pageData.titleName2: The Effect of Light on Seed Germination

images.altText: Magnified immune cells in a cluster formation

pageData.text: Plant seeds can be dormant for extended periods of time. During the dormant state, seeds can withstand harsher conditions than full-grown plants, and they can <button class='glossary-text'>germinate</button> as soon as environmental conditions are favorable. Seed germination can be triggered by environmental factors, including humidity, temperature, and light. This experiment will investigate seed germination activation by light penetration. The experiment tests different light wavelengths and their effects on seed germination.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: The Effect of Light on Seed Germination

text: Explain the relationship between wavelength of light and energy, and simulate light penetration through foliage and soil.
Describe the effects of light as a trigger for seed germination.
Determine which light colors (wavelengths) have the greatest stimulatory effect on seed germination using the appropriate positive and negative controls.
Calculate germination rates and seedling vigor indices of lettuce seeds under different wavelengths of light.

pageData.text: Have you ever driven past a building with windows emitting a purple glow? It might be because this space is being used to grow plants indoors. Plants are sensitive to the wavelength of light throughout their life cycle. <button class='glossary-text'>Phytochromes</button> are photo-responsive pigments that help the plant determine seasons and whether to continue growing or not. The purple light is a combination of red and blue wavelengths, which are absorbed most readily by chlorophyll for photosynthesis. By growing plants indoors under purple lights, food can be grown all year round. This is especially important in areas with short growing seasons or in urban environments where space may be an issue. These indoor farms can also be set up to use less water, fewer nutrients and have better pest control. Using high efficiency LEDs and only the highest-impact wavelengths of light can also reduce the carbon footprint of indoor farming. Additionally, the exact color ratio and intensity of these lights can be manipulated to optimize growth for different species to increase yield and even nutritional content.<sup>1</sup>

1Higgins, A. (2018, November 6). High-tech farmers are using LED lights in ways that seem to border on science fiction. The Washington Post.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2018/lifestyle/led-growing/

Vertical Grow by Arkansas Agricultural Experiment Station is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/89175420@N02/51139773752/in/photostream/

pageData.desc: Plants growing on a series of vertically stacked trays under purple lights.
pageData.altText: Plants growing on a series of vertically stacked trays under purple lights.

pageData.subTitle: Seed Germination
pageData.text: Plants cannot avoid unfavorable climatic conditions, which range from temperature extremes (hot versus cold), water availability (drought versus flood), and inclement light (full sun versus total shade). To increase survival under unfavorable conditions, mature plant seeds are in a dormant, metabolic state and enclosed within a protective coat when they are released from the mother plant. The seeds remain in this dormant state until the environmental conditions are favorable for the seed to <button class='glossary-text'>germinate</button>.

Seeds of different plant species have different requirements to trigger germination. The germination of many types of grasses, fireweed, evening primrose, and lettuce seeds is stimulated by exposure to a short period of light. Conversely, light can inhibit germination in other plants such as garlic and several species of the lily family. One of the best understood examples of the stimulatory effect of light is in lettuce seed germination. Lettuce seeds germinate when exposed to light, whereas keeping the seeds in darkness prolongs dormancy. Only a small intensity of light is necessary to trigger germination. <button class='glossary-text'>Incident light</button> (light directly shining on an object) is a signal that indicates the seed is close enough to the surface for the seedling to emerge and develop photosynthetic machinery before the stored energy and materials are completely consumed.

The light is only needed to trigger germination, however. After the start of germination, seeds use their stored energy and metabolites to support seedling growth. A pulse of light by itself is not sufficient to trigger seed germination since this can be caused by wind removing some leaves or snow from the soil. A longer period of light is needed to indicate that the environmental conditions are now favorable for growth. Exposing the seeds to one small burst of red light may not be enough to induce germination; prolonged exposure to red light is required.

<button class='glossary-text'>Visible light</button> is not one color, but consists of a spectrum of colors. These colors have different wavelengths. Colors with the shortest wavelengths are violet and blue, with wavelengths of 380-495 nm (nanometers). Colors with the longest wavelengths are red and far-red (very dark red between red and infra-red light), with wavelengths of 620-750 nm. Red (~620 nm) and far-red (~750 nm) wavelengths are important for seed germination. Figure 1 shows the spectrum of wavelength colors in visible light.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Figure 1 shows a drawing of the spectrum of wavelength colors in visible light with a scale ranging from 400 -700 nm going from (left to right) from purple, to navy, to turquoise, to green, to yellow, to orange, to red. Above the visible light spectrum there is also a scale that shows the other forms of light starting with gamma and moving towards x-rays, ultra violet light, into the visible light spectrum, then infrared and into radio waves.
pageData.desc: Figure 1: Figure 1 shows a drawing of the spectrum of wavelength colors in visible light with a scale ranging from 400 -700 nm going from (left to right) from purple, to navy, to turquoise, to green, to yellow, to orange, to red. Above the visible light spectrum there is also a scale that shows the other forms of light starting with gamma and moving towards x-rays, ultra violet light, into the visible light spectrum, then infrared and into radio waves.

pageData.text: Longer wavelengths of light penetrate more deeply into the soil layers. For example, red light penetrates soil more deeply than blue light. The presence or absence of red light is a signal of light availability, which stimulates seed germination. The phenomenon of seed germination under the influence of specific light wavelengths is called <button class='glossary-text'>photoblasty</button>.

Plants have evolved to produce a pigment that absorbs red and far-red light called a <button class='glossary-text'>phytochrome</button>. This pigment undergoes changes in its conformational structure under the influence of red and far-red light. On reacting with red light, the change in phytochrome structure activates the dormant seed and triggers germination. By contrast, far-red light does not trigger germination and keeps the seeds in a dormant state. This process of activating chlorophyll by sunlight during photosynthesis triggering germination in the phytochrome is called <button class='glossary-text'>photoactivation</button>. Shorter wavelength lights, such as blue light, slow the germination process. Although red light is a crucial factor that triggers germination, other environmental factors such as temperature, water, and humidity also play a role. Figure 2 shows the phytochrome absorption spectrum for plants.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Drawing of a graph that shows the phytochrome absorption spectrum for plants. With % of phytochrome at 666nm on the y-axis and wavelength in nm on the x-axis there is a line starting at 300 nm that forms a small curve and then a larger curve at 400 and 650 nm, respectively.
pageData.desc: Figure 2: Drawing of a graph that shows the phytochrome absorption spectrum for plants. With % of phytochrome at 666nm on the y-axis and wavelength in nm on the x-axis there is a line starting at 300 nm that forms a small curve and then a larger curve at 400 and 650 nm, respectively.

pageData.question: What type of light exposure is needed to trigger seed germination?

options.text: prolonged exposure to red light
prolonged exposure to blue light
a pulse of any light

prolonged exposure to UV

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A pulse of light by itself is not sufficient to trigger seed germination; prolonged exposure to red light is required.

pageData.question: What does prolonged exposure to red light represent for a dormant seed?

options.text: There is enough light available for the seedling to photosynthesize after germinating.
The seed is deep enough in the soil to grow a mature root system before germinating.
It is nighttime and conditions are not favorable for germination.
It is winter and conditions are too cold for germination.
It is summer and conditions are too hot for germination.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The amount of red light is a signal of light availability and represents favorable germinating conditions for dormant seeds.

pageData.subTitle: Investigation Calculations
pageData.text: In this investigation, you will be asked to calculate the germination rates and seedling vigor indices of lettuce seeds to see how they are affected by different wavelengths of . Different colors of filters will simulate sunlight penetrating foliage and soil to analyze the seed growth. The ) will allow you to determine how many seeds are germinating, per day, out of the total amount of seeds present. This rate will be calculated for each day of light exposure using the following equation:

pageData.desc: Equation 1: Formula for calculating seed germination rate (Gr) which is the number of seeds germinated on Day X divided by the total number of seeds in the dish, all multiplied by 100%.
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Formula for calculating seed germination rate (Gr) which is the number of seeds germinated on Day X divided by the total number of seeds in the dish, all multiplied by 100%.

pageData.text: The effect a specific light wavelength has on the germination of the seeds (Gl) will then be calculated using the data recorded on the last day of each treatment (Day 5), along with the number of seeds in the white light control from Day 5. The following equation will be used:

pageData.altText: Equation 2: Formula for the number of seeds germinated for each treatment divided by the number of seeds germinated for the white light control all multiplied by 100% equals the germination of seeds.
pageData.desc: Equation 2: Formula for the number of seeds germinated for each treatment divided by the number of seeds germinated for the white light control all multiplied by 100% equals the germination of seeds.

pageData.text: In scientific experiments, there are often control groups. These groups are treated the same way as the experimental groups except they are not exposed to the variable being tested (in this experiment, the wavelength of light). There are two different types of control groups: positive and negative.

The researcher does not expect to see any effect in the negative control group. For example, in a medical trial, a negative control group might be a placebo group, which received a treatment (e.g., a sugar pill) resembling a drug but containing no medicinal substances. The researcher would not expect the negative control group to have a change in condition because they would not receive the actual drug. The researcher would then compare the condition of the placebo group to that of a group given the drug. If both groups showed a change in condition, then the drug may not work; however, if only the drug-treated group showed a change in condition, this may be evidence that the drug is effective. In this experiment, the âdarkâ dish is the negative control.

The researcher does expect to see a specific effect in the positive control group. For example, when testing for the presence of a certain chemical, a researcher will run the test with a known material containing that chemical to ensure the test is working properly. If this test does not give a positive result, then the researcher knows the test is flawed and will not produce reliable results. If the test does produce a positive result, then the researcher knows that the test is working and will conduct the test on the material of unknown composition. In this experiment, the âwhite lightâ dish is the positive control.

Along with the <button class='glossary-text'>seed germination rates</button> and light wavelength effects on it, the length that the <button class='glossary-text'>germinated</button> seedlings become is an important factor to consider when determining the effects a specific wavelength of light has on the growth. Figure 3 shows a typical seedling and its important parts:

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Drawing of a typical seedling and its important parts. At the top there is the bud with two leaves sprouting out from it. Moving down the plant is the cotyledons, then the hypocotyl, and then the secondary and primary roots at the bottom.
pageData.desc: Figure 3: Drawing of a typical seedling and its important parts. At the top there is the bud with two leaves sprouting out from it. Moving down the plant is the cotyledons, then the hypocotyl, and then the secondary and primary roots at the bottom.

pageData.text: There are two main roots of <button class='glossary-text'>germinated</button> seeds: the primary and secondary roots. The primary root is the root that gives the seedling its main support which helps the seedling grow. The secondary roots are roots that grow off of this main, primary root to help position the seedling in the soil. Both types of roots are important for the absorption of water and nutrients from the soil for the seedling. The hypocotyl, or the stem of the seedling, protrudes from the secondary roots, with seed leaves, or <button class='glossary-text'>cotyledons</button>, found above this stem. A bud is formed at the top of this stem, which often has leaves growing from it as well.

In this experiment, you will be asked to measure the length of the germinated seedlings, from the primary root to the bud leaves, for each light treatment. Using the average lengths per light treatment, you will then calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>seedling vigor index</button> which shows how well (tall) seedlings grow under the different light indices using the germination rate data from Day 5 in the following equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 3: Formula for calculating seedling vigor index which is the average seedling length multiplied by the seed germination rate on day 5, all divided by 100.
pageData.desc: Equation 3: Formula for calculating seedling vigor index which is the average seedling length multiplied by the seed germination rate on day 5, all divided by 100.

pageData.question: Which of the following equations calculates the seedling vigor index?

options.text: (Average seedling length x G<sub>r Day 5</sub> ) / 100
(Seeds germinated for each treatment / Seeds germinated for white light control) x 100
(Seeds germinated on Day X / Total seeds in the dish) x 100
Average seedling length / G<sub>r Day X</sub>
Seeds germinated for each treatment x G<sub>r Day X</sub>

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. First, you will set up your Petri dishes. Then, you will add seeds and seal the Petri dishes. Next, you will cover each dish with the colored light filter and place them under the grow light. Each day, you will count the number of germinated seeds in each dish, then reseal the dishes and place them under the grow light. On Day 5, you will count the number of germinated seeds and calculate the germination rate. Then, you will calculate the effect of the wavelength of light on germination. Finally, you will measure the length of the germinated seedlings and calculate seedling vigor.

Finally, you will measure the length of the germinated seedlings and calculate seedling vigor.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

In Activity 1, you will <button class='glossary-text'>germinate</button> seeds in petri dishes with different light filters on them. You will observe their germination over 5 days and record the number of germinated seedlings in each dish. You will then calculate the rate of germination and the <button class='glossary-text'>seedling vigor index</button> to evaluate the effect of wavelength on germination.

Take 6 Petri dishes and label them as follows:
  • White light
  • Red light
  • Blue light
  • Yellow light
  • Green light
  • Dark
Insert one piece of filter paper into each of the 6 Petri dishes.
Fill a cup with room temperature tap water.
Using the plastic pipette, add tap water to the filters until they are saturated.
Drain any excess water from the filters.
Place 15 seeds on top of the saturated filter paper in each Petri dish, making sure to spread them out evenly.
Put the cover on each Petri dish, and wrap the outside edge of the dish with electrical tape to seal the inner chamber. Do not wrap the top of the cover (Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: The full experimental setup containing 6 Petri dishes covered with different colored filters that are taped (with electrical tape) onto the dishes. The first one has a cardboard cutout for a filter, the next is yellow, next is red, then blue, then green, and the last Petri dish has no filter cover so the seeds in the dish are visible.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: The full experimental setup containing 6 Petri dishes covered with different colored filters that are taped (with electrical tape) onto the dishes. The first one has a cardboard cutout for a filter, the next is yellow, next is red, then blue, then green, and the last Petri dish has no filter cover so the seeds in the dish are visible.

pageData.text: Cover the Petri dish marked âDarkâ with a circle shaped cardboard cutout (Figure 4). This is the negative control for the germination experiment.

Cover the other Petri dishes with the appropriate filter colors (i.e., place the red filter over the Petri dish labeled âRed lightâ) and wrap the outside edge of the dishes with electrical tape as well. No filter is needed for the Petri dish labeled âWhite lightâ (positive control).

Place the grow lights over the Petri dishes at a distance of 10â15 cm, making sure that the light is evenly distributed to all 6 Petri dishes (including the negative control covered with cardboard). This full experimental setup is shown in Figure 4.

Each day, carefully open the Petri dishes and count the number of seeds that have in each. Close the Petri dishes as soon as the seeds have been counted to avoid drying of the filter paper. Reseal the edge of each Petri dish with electrical tape, place the correct filter over each Petri dish as before, and place the dishes back under the grow light. Record the numbers of germinated seeds for each day in Data Table 1.
Seeds that have germinated will have a seed coat that split open, and a short root and shoot emerging from the seed.
Count the total number of seedlings germinated for each treatment, and record this data in the total seeds germinated row in Data Table 1.
Calculate the germination rate (Gr) for each day, and record in Data Table 2.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: Formula for calculating seed germination rate (Gr) which is the number of seeds germinated on Day X divided by the total number of seeds in the dish, all multiplied by 100%.
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Formula for calculating seed germination rate (Gr) which is the number of seeds germinated on Day X divided by the total number of seeds in the dish, all multiplied by 100%.

pageData.text: Calculate the effect of light wavelength on germination (Gl) for each treatment. Use the data recorded on Day 5 for each treatment, and use the number of germinated seeds in white light on Day 5 as the white light control. Calculate the effect of light wavelength for each day using the following formula. Record this data in Data Table 3.

pageData.desc: Equation 2: Formula for the number of seeds germinated for each treatment divided by the number of seeds germinated for the white light control all multiplied by 100% equals the germination of seeds.
pageData.altText: Equation 2: Formula for the number of seeds germinated for each treatment divided by the number of seeds germinated for the white light control all multiplied by 100% equals the germination of seeds.

pageData.text: Measure the length (in cm) of all germinated seedlings (from the primary root to the bud leaves) for each light treatment on Day 5 and record this in Data Table 4. Then, calculate the average seedling length per treatment by adding all lengths per treatment and dividing by the number of seeds germinated. Record the average seedling lengths in Data Table 4.

Calculate how well (how tall) seedlings grow under the different light treatments using Equation 3. This is called the . Use the data for germination rate on Day 5 from Data Table 1, and use the average seedling length calculated in Step 4 (and in Data Table 4). Record the seedling vigor index in Data Table 5.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: Formula for calculating seedling vigor index which is the average seedling length multiplied by the seed germination rate on day 5, all divided by 100.
pageData.desc: Equation 3: Formula for calculating seedling vigor index which is the average seedling length multiplied by the seed germination rate on day 5, all divided by 100.

text: Carefully remove the colored filters from the Petri dishes and throw them in the household trash.

If performing other experiments involving <button class='glossary-text'>germinated</button> lettuce seedlings, save for later use. Place any ungerminated seeds on a freshly wetted piece of filter paper under a grow light, and use these seedlings when they have germinated.
If no other experiments are to be performed using lettuce seeds, dispose of the ungerminated seeds and germinated seedlings in the household or yard waste.
Dispose of all other waste generated during this investigation in the household trash. Discard water in the sink.

text: Which light color would be expected to best stimulate seed germination? Did your results support this? Explain your answer.
How were the positive and negative control groups useful in interpreting the results of this experiment?
Why look at seedling vigor index in addition to germination rate in this experiment?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Figure 1 shows a drawing of the spectrum of wavelength colors in visible light with a scale ranging from 400 -700 nm going from (left to right) from purple, to navy, to turquoise, to green, to yellow, to orange, to red. Above the visible light spectrum there is also a scale that shows the other forms of light starting with gamma and moving towards x-rays, ultra violet light, into the visible light spectrum, then infrared and into radio waves.

Figure 2: Drawing of a graph that shows the phytochrome absorption spectrum for plants. With % of phytochrome at 666nm on the y-axis and wavelength in nm on the x-axis there is a line starting at 300 nm that forms a small curve and then a larger curve at 400 and 650 nm, respectively.
pageData.content: Figure 2. Phytochrome absorption spectrum for plants

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Formula for calculating seed germination rate (Gr) which is the number of seeds germinated on Day X divided by the total number of seeds in the dish, all multiplied by 100%.
Equation 2: Formula for the number of seeds germinated for each treatment divided by the number of seeds germinated for the white light control all multiplied by 100% equals the germination of seeds.
pageData.content: Equation 2. Effect of light wavelength on germination rate equation

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Drawing of a typical seedling and its important parts. At the top there is the bud with two leaves sprouting out from it. Moving down the plant is the cotyledons, then the hypocotyl, and then the secondary and primary roots at the bottom.
Equation 3: Formula for calculating seedling vigor index which is the average seedling length multiplied by the seed germination rate on day 5, all divided by 100.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. First, you will set up your Petri dishes. Then, you will add seeds and seal the Petri dishes. Next, you will cover each dish with the colored light filter and place them under the grow light. Each day, you will count the number of germinated seeds in each dish, then reseal the dishes and place them under the grow light. On Day 5, you will count the number of germinated seeds and calculate the germination rate. Then, you will calculate the effect of the wavelength of light on germination. Finally, you will measure the length of the germinated seedlings and calculate seedling vigor.

Figure 4: The full experimental setup containing 6 Petri dishes covered with different colored filters that are taped (with electrical tape) onto the dishes. The first one has a cardboard cutout for a filter, the next is yellow, next is red, then blue, then green, and the last Petri dish has no filter cover so the seeds in the dish are visible.

data.title: Germinate
data.content: to develop from a seed or spore after a period of dormancy

data.title: Incident light
data.content: A light shining directly on an object

data.title: Photoactivation
data.content: The process of activating chlorophyll by sunlight during photosynthesis which triggers germination in the phytochrome

data.title: Photoblasty
data.content: The phenomenon of seed germination under the influence of specific light wavelengths

data.title: Phytochrome
data.content: A pigment in plants that absorbs red and far-red light

data.title: Seed germination rate (G<sub>r</sub>)
data.content: The amount of seeds germinating per day as a percentage of the total seeds present

data.title: Seedling vigor index
data.content: The measure of how well (tall) seedlings grow under different light indices

data.title: Visible light
data.content: Light visible to the eye; consists of a spectrum of colors
